page.title: 04THE HISTORY OF DALRY(KIRK)
page.content: St.John's Clachan of Dalry developed near St.John's Kirk and the twelfth century motte beside the Water of Ken. The clachan (village or fairm toun) was a resting place for pilgrims going to the shrine of St. Ninian at Whithorn, notably James IV. In the churchyard under a tombstone, possibly lettered by Old Mortality,lie two Covenanters shot by Claverhouse for their religious beliefs in 1684. Robert Burns based his narrative poem Tam o' Shanter on the experience of Adam Forster who was chased across the river by witches whom he had seen dancing in the church.Invoking the name of God for protection, he traced a circle round himself and his mare with his sword. The oval Witches' Score, later marked as a shallow ditch by Adam and later farmers,is still visible on Waterside Hill.
